  54  """ 
  55  Pure Python PNG Reader/Writer 
  56   
  57  This Python module implements support for PNG images (see PNG 
  58  specification at http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110/ ). It reads 
  59  and writes PNG files with all allowable bit depths (1/2/4/8/16/24/32/48/64 
  60  bits per pixel) and colour combinations: greyscale (1/2/4/8/16 bit); RGB, 
  61  RGBA, LA (greyscale with alpha) with 8/16 bits per channel; colour mapped 
  62  images (1/2/4/8 bit).  Adam7 interlacing is supported for reading and 
  63  writing.  A number of optional chunks can be specified (when writing) 
  64  and understood (when reading): ``tRNS``, ``bKGD``, ``gAMA``. 
  65   
  66  For help, type ``import png; help(png)`` in your python interpreter. 
  67   
  68  A good place to start is the :class:`Reader` and :class:`Writer` classes. 
  69   
  70  Requires Python 2.3.  Limited support is available for Python 2.2, but 
  71  not everything works.  Best with Python 2.4 and higher.  Installation is 
  72  trivial, but see the ``README.txt`` file (with the source distribution) 
  73  for details. 
  74   
  75  This file can also be used as a command-line utility to convert 
  76  `Netpbm <http://netpbm.sourceforge.net/>`_ PNM files to PNG, and the reverse conversion from PNG to 
  77  PNM. The interface is similar to that of the ``pnmtopng`` program from 
  78  Netpbm.  Type ``python png.py --help`` at the shell prompt 
  79  for usage and a list of options. 
  80   
  81  A note on spelling and terminology 
  82  ---------------------------------- 
  83   
  84  Generally British English spelling is used in the documentation.  So 
  85  that's "greyscale" and "colour".  This not only matches the author's 
  86  native language, it's also used by the PNG specification. 
  87   
  88  The major colour models supported by PNG (and hence by PyPNG) are: 
  89  greyscale, RGB, greyscale--alpha, RGB--alpha.  These are sometimes 
  90  referred to using the abbreviations: L, RGB, LA, RGBA.  In this case 
  91  each letter abbreviates a single channel: *L* is for Luminance or Luma or 
  92  Lightness which is the channel used in greyscale images; *R*, *G*, *B* stand 
  93  for Red, Green, Blue, the components of a colour image; *A* stands for 
  94  Alpha, the opacity channel (used for transparency effects, but higher 
  95  values are more opaque, so it makes sense to call it opacity). 
  96   
  97  A note on formats 
  98  ----------------- 
  99   
 100  When getting pixel data out of this module (reading) and presenting 
 101  data to this module (writing) there are a number of ways the data could 
 102  be represented as a Python value.  Generally this module uses one of 
 103  three formats called "flat row flat pixel", "boxed row flat pixel", and 
 104  "boxed row boxed pixel".  Basically the concern is whether each pixel 
 105  and each row comes in its own little tuple (box), or not. 
 106   
 107  Consider an image that is 3 pixels wide by 2 pixels high, and each pixel 
 108  has RGB components: 
 109   
 110  Boxed row flat pixel:: 
 111   
 112    list([R,G,B, R,G,B, R,G,B], 
 113         [R,G,B, R,G,B, R,G,B]) 
 114   
 115  Each row appears as its own list, but the pixels are flattened so that 
 116  three values for one pixel simply follow the three values for the previous 
 117  pixel.  This is the most common format used, because it provides a good 
 118  compromise between space and convenience.  PyPNG regards itself as 
 119  at liberty to replace any sequence type with any sufficiently compatible 
 120  other sequence type; in practice each row is an array (from the array 
 121  module), and the outer list is sometimes an iterator rather than an 
 122  explicit list (so that streaming is possible). 
 123   
 124  Flat row flat pixel:: 
 125   
 126    [R,G,B, R,G,B, R,G,B, 
 127     R,G,B, R,G,B, R,G,B] 
 128   
 129  The entire image is one single giant sequence of colour values. 
 130  Generally an array will be used (to save space), not a list. 
 131   
 132  Boxed row boxed pixel:: 
 133   
 134    list([ (R,G,B), (R,G,B), (R,G,B) ], 
 135         [ (R,G,B), (R,G,B), (R,G,B) ]) 
 136   
 137  Each row appears in its own list, but each pixel also appears in its own 
 138  tuple.  A serious memory burn in Python. 
 139   
 140  In all cases the top row comes first, and for each row the pixels are 
 141  ordered from left-to-right.  Within a pixel the values appear in the 
 142  order, R-G-B-A (or L-A for greyscale--alpha). 
 143   
 144  There is a fourth format, mentioned because it is used internally, 
 145  is close to what lies inside a PNG file itself, and has some support 
 146  from the public API.  This format is called packed.  When packed, 
 147  each row is a sequence of bytes (integers from 0 to 255), just as 
 148  it is before PNG scanline filtering is applied.  When the bit depth 
 149  is 8 this is essentially the same as boxed row flat pixel; when the 
 150  bit depth is less than 8, several pixels are packed into each byte; 
 151  when the bit depth is 16 (the only value more than 8 that is supported 
 152  by the PNG image format) each pixel value is decomposed into 2 bytes 
 153  (and `packed` is a misnomer).  This format is used by the 
 154  :meth:`Writer.write_packed` method.  It isn't usually a convenient 
 155  format, but may be just right if the source data for the PNG image 
 156  comes from something that uses a similar format (for example, 1-bit 
 157  BMPs, or another PNG file). 
 158

 339 -def interleave_planes(ipixels, apixels, ipsize, apsize): 

 340      """ 
 341      Interleave (colour) planes, e.g. RGB + A = RGBA. 
 342   
 343      Return an array of pixels consisting of the `ipsize` elements of data 
 344      from each pixel in `ipixels` followed by the `apsize` elements of data 
 345      from each pixel in `apixels`.  Conventionally `ipixels` and 
 346      `apixels` are byte arrays so the sizes are bytes, but it actually 
 347      works with any arrays of the same type.  The returned array is the 
 348      same type as the input arrays which should be the same type as each other. 
 349      """ 
 350   
 351      itotal = len(ipixels) 
 352      atotal = len(apixels) 
 353      newtotal = itotal + atotal 
 354      newpsize = ipsize + apsize 
 355      # Set up the output buffer 
 356      # See http://www.python.org/doc/2.4.4/lib/module-array.html#l2h-1356 
 357      out = array(ipixels.typecode) 
 358      # It's annoying that there is no cheap way to set the array size :-( 
 359      out.extend(ipixels) 
 360      out.extend(apixels) 
 361      # Interleave in the pixel data 
 362      for i in range(ipsize): 
 363          out[i:newtotal:newpsize] = ipixels[i:itotal:ipsize] 
 364      for i in range(apsize): 
 365          out[i+ipsize:newtotal:newpsize] = apixels[i:atotal:apsize] 
 366      return out

 368 -def check_palette(palette): 

 369      """Check a palette argument (to the :class:`Writer` class) for validity. 
 370      Returns the palette as a list if okay; raises an exception otherwise. 
 371      """ 
 372   
 373      # None is the default and is allowed. 
 374      if palette is None: 
 375          return None 
 376   
 377      p = list(palette) 
 378      if not (0 < len(p) <= 256): 
 379          raise ValueError("a palette must have between 1 and 256 entries") 
 380      seen_triple = False 
 381      for i,t in enumerate(p): 
 382          if len(t) not in (3,4): 
 383              raise ValueError( 
 384                "palette entry %d: entries must be 3- or 4-tuples." % i) 
 385          if len(t) == 3: 
 386              seen_triple = True 
 387          if seen_triple and len(t) == 4: 
 388              raise ValueError( 
 389                "palette entry %d: all 4-tuples must precede all 3-tuples" % i) 
 390          for x in t: 
 391              if int(x) != x or not(0 <= x <= 255): 
 392                  raise ValueError( 
 393                    "palette entry %d: values must be integer: 0 <= x <= 255" % i) 
 394      return p

 412 -class Writer: 

 413      """ 
 414      PNG encoder in pure Python.

 417 -    def __init__(self, width=None, height=None, 
 418                   size=None, 
 419                   greyscale=False, 
 420                   alpha=False, 
 421                   bitdepth=8, 
 422                   palette=None, 
 423                   transparent=None, 
 424                   background=None, 
 425                   gamma=None, 
 426                   compression=None, 
 427                   interlace=False, 
 428                   bytes_per_sample=None, # deprecated 
 429                   planes=None, 
 430                   colormap=None, 
 431                   maxval=None, 
 432                   chunk_limit=2**20): 

 433          """ 
 434          Create a PNG encoder object. 
 435   
 436          Arguments: 
 437   
 438          width, height 
 439            Image size in pixels, as two separate arguments. 
 440          size 
 441            Image size (w,h) in pixels, as single argument. 
 442          greyscale 
 443            Input data is greyscale, not RGB. 
 444          alpha 
 445            Input data has alpha channel (RGBA or LA). 
 446          bitdepth 
 447            Bit depth: from 1 to 16. 
 448          palette 
 449            Create a palette for a colour mapped image (colour type 3). 
 450          transparent 
 451            Specify a transparent colour (create a ``tRNS`` chunk). 
 452          background 
 453            Specify a default background colour (create a ``bKGD`` chunk). 
 454          gamma 
 455            Specify a gamma value (create a ``gAMA`` chunk). 
 456          compression 
 457            zlib compression level (1-9). 
 458          interlace 
 459            Create an interlaced image. 
 460          chunk_limit 
 461            Write multiple ``IDAT`` chunks to save memory. 
 462   
 463          The image size (in pixels) can be specified either by using the 
 464          `width` and `height` arguments, or with the single `size` 
 465          argument.  If `size` is used it should be a pair (*width*, 
 466          *height*). 
 467   
 468          `greyscale` and `alpha` are booleans that specify whether 
 469          an image is greyscale (or colour), and whether it has an 
 470          alpha channel (or not). 
 471   
 472          `bitdepth` specifies the bit depth of the source pixel values. 
 473          Each source pixel value must be an integer between 0 and 
 474          ``2**bitdepth-1``.  For example, 8-bit images have values 
 475          between 0 and 255.  PNG only stores images with bit depths of 
 476          1,2,4,8, or 16.  When `bitdepth` is not one of these values, 
 477          the next highest valid bit depth is selected, and an ``sBIT`` 
 478          (significant bits) chunk is generated that specifies the original 
 479          precision of the source image.  In this case the supplied pixel 
 480          values will be rescaled to fit the range of the selected bit depth. 
 481   
 482          The details of which bit depth / colour model combinations the 
 483          PNG file format supports directly, are somewhat arcane 
 484          (refer to the PNG specification for full details).  Briefly: 
 485          "small" bit depths (1,2,4) are only allowed with greyscale and 
 486          colour mapped images; colour mapped images cannot have bit depth 
 487          16. 
 488   
 489          For colour mapped images (in other words, when the `palette` 
 490          argument is specified) the `bitdepth` argument must match one of 
 491          the valid PNG bit depths: 1, 2, 4, or 8.  (It is valid to have a 
 492          PNG image with a palette and an ``sBIT`` chunk, but the meaning 
 493          is slightly different; it would be awkward to press the 
 494          `bitdepth` argument into service for this.) 
 495   
 496          The `palette` option, when specified, causes a colour mapped image 
 497          to be created: the PNG colour type is set to 3; greyscale 
 498          must not be set; alpha must not be set; transparent must 
 499          not be set; the bit depth must be 1,2,4, or 8.  When a colour 
 500          mapped image is created, the pixel values are palette indexes 
 501          and the `bitdepth` argument specifies the size of these indexes 
 502          (not the size of the colour values in the palette). 
 503   
 504          The palette argument value should be a sequence of 3- or 
 505          4-tuples.  3-tuples specify RGB palette entries; 4-tuples 
 506          specify RGBA palette entries.  If both 4-tuples and 3-tuples 
 507          appear in the sequence then all the 4-tuples must come 
 508          before all the 3-tuples.  A ``PLTE`` chunk is created; if there 
 509          are 4-tuples then a ``tRNS`` chunk is created as well.  The 
 510          ``PLTE`` chunk will contain all the RGB triples in the same 
 511          sequence; the ``tRNS`` chunk will contain the alpha channel for 
 512          all the 4-tuples, in the same sequence.  Palette entries 
 513          are always 8-bit. 
 514   
 515          If specified, the `transparent` and `background` parameters must 
 516          be a tuple with three integer values for red, green, blue, or 
 517          a simple integer (or singleton tuple) for a greyscale image. 
 518   
 519          If specified, the `gamma` parameter must be a positive number 
 520          (generally, a float).  A ``gAMA`` chunk will be created.  Note that 
 521          this will not change the values of the pixels as they appear in 
 522          the PNG file, they are assumed to have already been converted 
 523          appropriately for the gamma specified. 
 524   
 525          The `compression` argument specifies the compression level 
 526          to be used by the ``zlib`` module.  Higher values are likely 
 527          to compress better, but will be slower to compress.  The 
 528          default for this argument is ``None``; this does not mean 
 529          no compression, rather it means that the default from the 
 530          ``zlib`` module is used (which is generally acceptable). 
 531   
 532          If `interlace` is true then an interlaced image is created 
 533          (using PNG's so far only interace method, *Adam7*).  This does not 
 534          affect how the pixels should be presented to the encoder, rather 
 535          it changes how they are arranged into the PNG file.  On slow 
 536          connexions interlaced images can be partially decoded by the 
 537          browser to give a rough view of the image that is successively 
 538          refined as more image data appears. 
 539           
 540          .. note :: 
 541           
 542            Enabling the `interlace` option requires the entire image 
 543            to be processed in working memory. 
 544   
 545          `chunk_limit` is used to limit the amount of memory used whilst 
 546          compressing the image.  In order to avoid using large amounts of 
 547          memory, multiple ``IDAT`` chunks may be created. 
 548          """ 
 549   
 550          # At the moment the `planes` argument is ignored; 
 551          # its purpose is to act as a dummy so that 
 552          # ``Writer(x, y, **info)`` works, where `info` is a dictionary 
 553          # returned by Reader.read and friends. 
 554          # Ditto for `colormap`.

 560              try: 
 561                  return int(x) == x

 565          def check_color(c, which): 
 566              """Checks that a colour argument for transparent or 
 567              background options is the right form.  Also "corrects" bare 
 568              integers to 1-tuples. 
 569              """ 
 570   
 571              if c is None: 
 572                  return c 
 573              if greyscale: 
 574                  try: 
 575                      l = len(c) 
 576                  except TypeError: 
 577                      c = (c,) 
 578                  if len(c) != 1: 
 579                      raise ValueError("%s for greyscale must be 1-tuple" % 
 580                          which) 
 581                  if not isinteger(c[0]): 
 582                      raise ValueError( 
 583                          "%s colour for greyscale must be integer" % 
 584                          which) 
 585              else: 
 586                  if not (len(c) == 3 and 
 587                          isinteger(c[0]) and 
 588                          isinteger(c[1]) and 
 589                          isinteger(c[2])): 
 590                      raise ValueError( 
 591                          "%s colour must be a triple of integers" % 
 592                          which) 
 593              return c 

 594   
 595          if size: 
 596              if len(size) != 2: 
 597                  raise ValueError( 
 598                    "size argument should be a pair (width, height)") 
 599              if width is not None and width != size[0]: 
 600                  raise ValueError( 
 601                    "size[0] (%r) and width (%r) should match when both are used." 
 602                      % (size[0], width))

1084 -def filter_scanline(type, line, fo, prev=None): 

1085      """Apply a scanline filter to a scanline.  `type` specifies the 
1086      filter type (0 to 4); `line` specifies the current (unfiltered) 
1087      scanline as a sequence of bytes; `prev` specifies the previous 
1088      (unfiltered) scanline as a sequence of bytes. `fo` specifies the 
1089      filter offset; normally this is size of a pixel in bytes (the number 
1090      of bytes per sample times the number of channels), but when this is 
1091      < 1 (for bit depths < 8) then the filter offset is 1. 
1092      """ 
1093   
1094      assert 0 <= type < 5 
1095   
1096      # The output array.  Which, pathetically, we extend one-byte at a 
1097      # time (fortunately this is linear). 
1098      out = array('B', [type]) 
1099   
1100      def sub(): 
1101          ai = -fo 
1102          for x in line: 
1103              if ai >= 0: 
1104                  x = (x - line[ai]) & 0xff 
1105              out.append(x) 
1106              ai += 1 

1107      def up(): 
1108          for i,x in enumerate(line): 
1109              x = (x - prev[i]) & 0xff 
1110              out.append(x) 
1111      def average(): 
1112          ai = -fo 
1113          for i,x in enumerate(line): 
1114              if ai >= 0: 
1115                  x = (x - ((line[ai] + prev[i]) >> 1)) & 0xff 
1116              else: 
1117                  x = (x - (prev[i] >> 1)) & 0xff 
1118              out.append(x) 
1119              ai += 1 
1120      def paeth(): 
1121          # http://www.w3.org/TR/PNG/#9Filter-type-4-Paeth 
1122          ai = -fo # also used for ci 
1123          for i,x in enumerate(line): 
1124              a = 0 
1125              b = prev[i] 
1126              c = 0 
1127   
1128              if ai >= 0: 
1129                  a = line[ai] 
1130                  c = prev[ai] 
1131              p = a + b - c 
1132              pa = abs(p - a) 
1133              pb = abs(p - b) 
1134              pc = abs(p - c) 
1135              if pa <= pb and pa <= pc: Pr = a 
1136              elif pb <= pc: Pr = b 
1137              else: Pr = c 
1138   
1139              x = (x - Pr) & 0xff 
1140              out.append(x) 
1141              ai += 1 
1142   
1143      if not prev: 
1144          # We're on the first line.  Some of the filters can be reduced 
1145          # to simpler cases which makes handling the line "off the top" 
1146          # of the image simpler.  "up" becomes "none"; "paeth" becomes 
1147          # "left" (non-trivial, but true). "average" needs to be handled 
1148          # specially. 
1149          if type == 2: # "up" 
1150              return line # type = 0 
1151          elif type == 3: 
1152              prev = [0]*len(line) 
1153          elif type == 4: # "paeth" 
1154              type = 1 
1155      if type == 0: 
1156          out.extend(line) 
1157      elif type == 1: 
1158          sub() 
1159      elif type == 2: 
1160          up() 
1161      elif type == 3:

1163      else: # type == 4 
1164          paeth()

1182      array the first axis is the height; the second axis is the width;

1197      ``'RGB'`` 
1198        colour image (3 channel) 
1199      ``'RGBA'`` 
1200        colour image with alpha (4 channel) 
1201   
1202      The mode string can also specify the bit depth (overriding how this 
1203      function normally derives the bit depth, see below).  Appending 
1204      ``';16'`` to the mode will cause the PNG to be 16 bits per channel; 
1205      any decimal from 1 to 16 can be used to specify the bit depth. 
1206   
1207      When a 2-dimensional array is used *mode* determines how many 
1208      channels the image has, and so allows the width to be derived from 
1209      the second array dimension. 
1210   
1211      The array is expected to be a ``numpy`` array, but it can be any 
1212      suitable Python sequence.  For example, a list of lists can be used: 
1213      ``png.from_array([[0, 255, 0], [255, 0, 255]], 'L')``.  The exact 
1214      rules are: ``len(a)`` gives the first dimension, height; 
1215      ``len(a[0])`` gives the second dimension; ``len(a[0][0])`` gives the 
1216      third dimension, unless an exception is raised in which case a 
1217      2-dimensional array is assumed.  It's slightly more complicated than 
1218      that because an iterator of rows can be used, and it all still 
1219      works.  Using an iterator allows data to be streamed efficiently. 
1220   
1221      The bit depth of the PNG is normally taken from the array element's 
1222      datatype (but if *mode* specifies a bitdepth then that is used 
1223      instead).  The array element's datatype is determined in a way which 
1224      is supposed to work both for ``numpy`` arrays and for Python 
1225      ``array.array`` objects.  A 1 byte datatype will give a bit depth of 
1226      8, a 2 byte datatype will give a bit depth of 16.  If the datatype 
1227      does not have an implicit size, for example it is a plain Python 
1228      list of lists, as above, then a default of 8 is used. 
1229   
1230      The *info* parameter is a dictionary that can be used to specify 
1231      metadata (in the same style as the arguments to the 
1232      :class:``png.Writer`` class).  For this function the keys that are 
1233      useful are: 
1234

2304  # === Legacy Version Support === 
2305   
2306  # :pyver:old:  PyPNG works on Python versions 2.3 and 2.2, but not 
2307  # without some awkward problems.  Really PyPNG works on Python 2.4 (and 
2308  # above); it works on Pythons 2.3 and 2.2 by virtue of fixing up 
2309  # problems here.  It's a bit ugly (which is why it's hidden down here). 
2310  # 
2311  # Generally the strategy is one of pretending that we're running on 
2312  # Python 2.4 (or above), and patching up the library support on earlier 
2313  # versions so that it looks enough like Python 2.4.  When it comes to 
2314  # Python 2.2 there is one thing we cannot patch: extended slices 
2315  # http://www.python.org/doc/2.3/whatsnew/section-slices.html. 
2316  # Instead we simply declare that features that are implemented using 
2317  # extended slices will not work on Python 2.2. 
2318  # 
2319  # In order to work on Python 2.3 we fix up a recurring annoyance involving 
2320  # the array type.  In Python 2.3 an array cannot be initialised with an 
2321  # array, and it cannot be extended with a list (or other sequence). 
2322  # Both of those are repeated issues in the code.  Whilst I would not 
2323  # normally tolerate this sort of behaviour, here we "shim" a replacement 
2324  # for array into place (and hope no-ones notices).  You never read this. 
2325  # 
2326  # In an amusing case of warty hacks on top of warty hacks... the array 
2327  # shimming we try and do only works on Python 2.3 and above (you can't 
2328  # subclass array.array in Python 2.2).  So to get it working on Python 
2329  # 2.2 we go for something much simpler and (probably) way slower. 
2330  try: 
2331      array('B').extend([]) 
2332      array('B', array('B')) 
2333  except: 
2334      # Expect to get here on Python 2.3 
2335      try:

2398  # === Internal Test Support === 
2399   
2400  # This section comprises the tests that are internally validated (as 
2401  # opposed to tests which produce output files that are externally 
2402  # validated).  Primarily they are unittests. 
2403   
2404  # Note that it is difficult to internally validate the results of 
2405  # writing a PNG file.  The only thing we can do is read it back in 
2406  # again, which merely checks consistency, not that the PNG file we 
2407  # produce is valid.

3457      def test_pattern(width, height, bitdepth, pattern): 
3458          """Create a single plane (monochrome) test pattern.  Returns a 
3459          flat row flat pixel array. 
3460          """ 
3461   
3462          maxval = 2**bitdepth-1

3472              for x in range(width): 
3473                  a.append(int(round(pfun(float(x)/fw, fy) * maxval))) 
3474          return a

3560      """

3571              break

3575              continue

3578              header[l[0]] = l[1] 
3579          else: 
3580              header[l[0]] += strtobytes(' ') + l[1]

3583      required = [strtobytes(x) for x in required] 
3584      WIDTH,HEIGHT,DEPTH,MAXVAL = required 
3585      present = [x for x in required if x in header] 
3586      if len(present) != len(required): 
3587          raise Error('PAM file must specify WIDTH, HEIGHT, DEPTH, and MAXVAL') 
3588      width = int(header[WIDTH]) 
3589      height = int(header[HEIGHT]) 
3590      depth = int(header[DEPTH]) 
3591      maxval = int(header[MAXVAL]) 
3592      if (width <= 0 or 
3593          height <= 0 or 
3594          depth <= 0 or 
3595          maxval <= 0): 
3596          raise Error(

3869                read_pnm_header(pgmfile, 'P5') 
3870              if amaxval != '255': 
3871                  raise NotImplementedError( 
3872                    'maxval %s not supported for alpha channel' % amaxval) 
3873              if (awidth, aheight) != (width, height): 
3874                  raise ValueError("alpha channel image size mismatch" 
3875                                   " (%s has %sx%s but %s has %sx%s)" 
3876                                   % (infilename, width, height, 
3877                                      options.alpha, awidth, aheight)) 
3878              writer.convert_ppm_and_pgm(infile, pgmfile, outfile) 
3879          else: 
3880              writer.convert_pnm(infile, outfile) 

3881

3884      try: 
3885          _main(sys.argv) 
3886      except Error, e: 
3887          print >>sys.stderr, e
